Literature Review: Systemic autoinflammatory diseases (SAIDs) represent a diverse group of conditions characterized by recurrent episodes of inflammation without the presence of high-titer autoantibodies or autoreactive T cells. The genetic underpinnings of these diseases have been a focal point of research, leading to significant advancements in understanding their pathogenesis. The discovery of the MEFV gene, responsible for familial Mediterranean fever (FMF), marked the beginning of a new era in the study of SAIDs. Since then, over 50 monogenic SAIDs have been identified, each with distinct clinical phenotypes and genetic mechanisms. The genetic architecture of SAIDs is complex and can be categorized into monogenic, digenic, polygenic, and somatic mutations. Monogenic SAIDs are caused by single-gene mutations, often inherited in an autosomal dominant or recessive pattern. For instance, mutations in the NLRP3 gene lead to cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes (CAPS), which include familial cold autoinflammatory syndrome (FCAS), Muckle-Wells syndrome (MWS), and neonatal-onset multisystem inflammatory disease (NOMID). These mutations result in the constitutive activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome, leading to excessive production of interleukin-1β (IL-1β) and subsequent inflammation. Digenic inheritance, where two different genes contribute to the disease phenotype, has also been observed in SAIDs. For example, mutations in both the PSTPIP1 and PYCARD genes can cause pyogenic arthritis, pyoderma gangrenosum, and acne (PAPA) syndrome. This highlights the importance of considering multiple genetic factors in the diagnosis and management of SAIDs. Polygenic SAIDs involve the interaction of multiple genetic variants, each contributing a small effect to the overall disease risk. Conditions such as Behçet's disease and periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, and cervical adenitis (PFAPA) syndrome are thought to have a polygenic basis. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified several loci associated with these conditions, including HLA-B51 for Behçet's disease and TNFAIP3 for PFAPA syndrome. Somatic mutations, which occur in non-germline cells, have also been implicated in the pathogenesis of SAIDs. Somatic hypermutation in the TNFRSF1A gene, for example, can lead to tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS). These mutations can arise de novo in specific tissues, leading to localized inflammation and disease manifestations. Epigenetic modifications, such as DNA methylation and histone modifications, play a crucial role in the regulation of gene expression and can influence the development of SAIDs. Studies have shown that aberrant DNA methylation patterns can lead to the dysregulation of inflammatory genes, contributing to the pathogenesis of SAIDs. For instance, hypomethylation of the NLRP3 promoter has been associated with increased NLRP3 expression and enhanced inflammasome activation in patients with CAPS. The clinical phenotypes of SAIDs are highly variable, ranging from mild, self-limiting episodes to severe, life-threatening conditions. Common symptoms include fever, rash, joint pain, and serositis. The age of onset and severity of symptoms can vary widely, even among individuals with the same genetic mutation. For example, patients with FMF typically present with recurrent fevers and abdominal pain, while those with TRAPS may experience prolonged febrile episodes and myalgia. Understanding the genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying SAIDs has led to the development of targeted therapies. IL-1 inhibitors, such as anakinra and canakinumab, have been highly effective in treating conditions like CAPS and FMF. These therapies work by blocking the action of IL-1β, thereby reducing inflammation and improving patient outcomes. In conclusion, the genetics of SAIDs is a multifaceted field that encompasses monogenic, digenic, polygenic, and somatic mutations, as well as epigenetic modifications. Advances in genomics and immunology have significantly enhanced our understanding of these diseases, leading to improved diagnostic tools and therapeutic options. Future research should focus on identifying novel genetic and epigenetic factors and developing personalized treatment strategies to better manage SAIDs.
